discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
vPC Delay Restore
After a vPC peer device reloads and comes back up, the routing protocol needs time to reconverge.
The recovering vPCs leg may black-hole routed traffic from access to core until Layer 3 connectivity is
reestablished.

Selected Answer: B
b is correct
B is right. https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ios-nx-os-software/nx-os-software/212589-understanding-vpc-election-process.html

B is correct - we allow time for the vpc to learn all the routing and have all its interfaces ready before we preempt on the reloaded switch 
https://community.cisco.com/t5/switching/hsrp-delay-minimum-amp-reload-question/td-p/3327186

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. During a vPC peer switch reload, there is packet loss between the server and the router. Which action must be taken to prevent this behavior during future reloads?

choices.D: Decrease the OSPF hello and dead interval timers.
choices.B: Increase the vPC delay restore timer.
choices.C: Disable vPC ARP synchronize on the vPC peers.
choices.A: Set the routed uplink ports of the Cisco Nexus peers as orphans.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
The correct answer is D - the access policy (the interface policy group) needs to have one single AAEP assigned (bcs its the same port/s). Then different physical domains can be used for the routed and switched domain.

choices.C: by mapping a single physical domain, mapped to the L3out and EPG interfaces
choices.A: by linking the interface policy group to multiple Attachable Access Entity Profiles
choices.B: with two interface policy groups that are linked to the same interface profile port selector
choices.D: with a single Attachable Access Entity Profile that is linked to the corresponding routed domain and physical domain

questions.question_text: A Cisco ACI engineer must configure an access port on a Cisco ACI leaf switch. The access policy should be configured so that it supports L3Out connectivity concurrently with several EPGs that are mapped to this interface with the static port method. How should the access policy be configured?

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer monitors ingress traffic from Host-A and all traffic for VLAN 20 from Host-B. Which configuration must be implemented to monitor and export traffic to Network Analyzer?

choices.D: SW-1(config)# monitor session 5 type erspan SW-1(config-erspan-src)# source interface ethernet 1/2 rx SW-1(config-erspan-src)# source interface ethernet 1/1 both SW-1(config-erspan-src)# destination ip 10.10.10.1 SW-1(config-erspan-src)# mtu 1000 SW-1(config-erspan-src)# no shut
choices.A: SW-1(config)# monitor session 5 SW-1(config-monitor)# source interface ethernet 1/2 rx SW-1(config-monitor)# source interface ethernet 1/1 tx SW-1(config-monitor)# source vlan 20 both SW-1(config-monitor)# destination ip 10.10.10.1 SW-1(config-monitor)# no shut
choices.C: SW-1(config)# monitor session 5 SW-1(config-monitor)# source interface ethernet 1/2 rx SW-1(config-monitor)# source interface ethernet 1/1 both SW-1(config-monitor)# source vlan 20 both SW-1(config-monitor)# destination interface ethernet 2/1 SW-1(config-monitor)# no shut
choices.B: SW-1(config)# monitor session 5 type erspan-source SW-1(config-erspan-src)# source interface ethernet 1/2 rx SW-1(config-erspan-src)# source vlan 20 both SW-1(config-erspan-src)# destination ip 10.10.10.1 SW-1(config-erspan-src)# erspan-id 111 SW-1(config-erspan-src)# no shut

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which action completes the vPC domain implementation?

discussion.content:
Correct to me is B
The question is around vPC domain implementation? As such, the vpc domain is missing the vrf information:
peer-keepalive destination 10.10.10.2 source 10.10.10.1 "vrf management" <---
Without this, keepalive won't succeed and the domain won't be formed.
Allowing vlans - by default all vlans are allowed - so D is incorrect.
Adding members to the vPC - if the vPC domain is not formed first, this is irrelevant.

must be C, peer-keepalive destination ipaddress source ipaddress | vrf {name | management vpc-keepalive}
 

Configures the IPv4 and IPv6 addresses for the remote end of the vPC peer-keepalive link.
https://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=3150966&seqNum=2 
and https://www.letsconfig.com/how-to-configure-cisco-nexus-vpc/

Selected Answer: A
You don't need to create another VRF, VRF mgmt already exits for default and the int mgmt0 it's already a menber of the VRF, so C is incorrect.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/nexus9000/sw/6-x/interfaces/configuration/guide/b_Cisco_Nexus_9000_Series_NX-OS_Interfaces_Configuration_Guide/b_Cisco_Nexus_9000_Series_NX-OS_Interfaces_Configuration_Guide_chapter_0111.html

comments.content:
management port and management VRF are the default for keepalive.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
As we are using mtmt links for keepalive of VPC we must specify VRF management (mgmt link vrf) in vpc config. Else the keep alive link will not work. Question is about VPC domain implementation and not allowing vlan's thru it or configuring VPC on specific ports so A and D are wrong. Mac on VPC domain is wrong also.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct.because vPC need
Answer is "C"

Selected Answer: A
Technically both A & C are right. But would opt for A as it's clearly missing memebrs.
A is correct.. all vlans are enable by default in vpc peer link
A is correct!! The rest of responses are incorrect and non-sense for vPC config
Member ports are ports going down to servers, other switches, etc.. The ports that are missing the port-channel info are for the peer-link (not member ports).. answer has to be C

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
A is correct, vpc peer link port channel is missing it's members eth1/1 and eth1/2

Selected Answer: C
Correct answer is C...by default all vlans are added to trunks, so they will not prevent the VPC config from operating. However, the keepalive will not work as configured as the vrf is not specified.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct. Portchannel is missing ports

Selected Answer: A
A is correct. Portchannel is missing ports

Selected Answer: A
The interfaces need to be added to the Portchannel. Configuring allowed VLANs on the vPC peer-link is optional.

choices.B: Configure the system MAC on the vPC domain.
choices.A: Add the vPC member ports to the vPC channel group.
choices.D: Allow VLANs on the vPC peer link member interfaces.
choices.C: Include the VRF management on the vPC domain.
